Issues.Title: fix(ivy): set namespace for host elements of dynamically created components
Issues.Body:
Prior to this change, element namespace was not set for host elements of dynamically created components that resulted in incorrect rendering in a browser. This commit adds the logic to pick and set correct namespace for host element when component is created dynamically.

Fixes #34256, #34866.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): host-styling throws assert exception inside *ngFor
Issues.Body:
Inside `*ngFor` the second run of the styling instructions can get into situation where it tries to read a value from a binding which has not yet executed. As a result the read is `NO_CHANGE` value and subsequent property read cause an exception as it is of wrong type.

Fix #35118

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): draft containsDirty alternative
Issues.Body: [Draft/test] - Currently, if the insertion component is OnPush, we always check the transplanted view at the declaration point. We could potentially check only if the insertion is *not* dirty. This would work in most cases, but could fail in one very specific case: backwards references (insertion checked before declaration) that also get marked dirty after change detection **and** there is a change in the declaration that was not available when the insertion was checked.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ivy): draft containsDirty alternative" (#35121)

Issues.Title: fix(animations): false positive when detecting Node in Webpack builds
Issues.Body:
We have to do some extra work in the animations module when we identify a Node environment which we determine based on the `process` global. The problem is that by default Webpack will polyfill the `process`, causing us to incorrectly identify it. These changes make it so that the check isn't thrown off by Webpack.

Fixes #35117.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(animations): false positive when detecting Node in Webpack builds" (#35134)

Issues.Title: build: adding a script to compare commits in master and stable branches
Issues.Body:
Adding a script that compares commits in master and patch branches and finds a delta between them. This is useful for release reviews, to make sure all the necessary commits are included into the patch branch and there is no discrepancy.

This script was inspired by the [compare-master-to-stable.js](https://github.com/angular/angular.js/blob/master/scripts/compare-master-to-stable.js) one that was used in AngularJS.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): narrow `NgIf` context variables in template type checker
Issues.Body: fix(ivy): narrow `NgIf` context variables in template type checker When the `NgIf` directive is used in a template, its context variables can be used to capture the bound value. This is typically used together with a pipe or function call, where the resulting value is captured in a context variable. There's two syntax forms available: 1. Binding to `NgIfContext.ngIf` using the `as` syntax: ```html {{user.name}} ``` 2. Binding to `NgIfContext.$implicit` using the `let` syntax: ```html {{user.name}} ``` Because of the semantics of `ngIf`, it is known that the captured context variable is non-nullable, however the template type checker would not consider them as such and still report errors when `strictNullTypes` is enabled. This commit updates `NgIf`'s context guard to make the types of the context variables non-nullable, avoiding the issue. Fixes #34572
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): narrow `NgIf` context variables in template type checker" (#35125)

Issues.Title: EventEmitter.emit() should only accept T, not T | undefined.
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ bug report

### Affected Package

@angular/core


### Is this a regression?

No


### Description

The signature of `EventEmiter.emit` was modelled according to the signature of rxjs' `Subject.next` (see #10058 ). But the signature of `Subject.next` has a [design flaw](https://github.com/ReactiveX/rxjs/issues/2852) which has been copied to `EventEmitter.emit`.

This issue is essentially the same as https://github.com/ReactiveX/rxjs/issues/2852 , but applied to angular's EventEmitter. See repro below for details.


## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction

```ts
const em = new EventEmitter<string>();
em.asObservable().subscribe(s => {
    s.substring(0, 1); // boom
});
em.emit();
```

### Expected behavior

A compile error at line 5

### Actual behavior

A runtime error at line 3

### Details

The signature of `emit` allows emitting `undefined` on an event emitter which declares a non-nullable type.
This defeats the whole purpose of typescript's --strictNullCheck flag.


## ğŸ”¥ Exception or Error

No error, that's the problem.


## ğŸŒ  Your Environment

All versions since #10058

## ğŸ”§ Suggested fix

The suggested fix is simple enough, but it is a breaking change:
- Make the parameter of `emit` non-optional. One can still write `em.emit()` provided the EventEmitter is of type `EventEmitter<void>`.
- Make the default type of T `void` instead of `any` (see [this](https://github.com/ReactiveX/rxjs/issues/5066#issuecomment-581462164)) for details.

```diff
diff --git a/packages/core/src/event_emitter.ts b/packages/core/src/event_emitter.ts
index 07143d9774..eaf84b7ad0 100644
--- a/packages/core/src/event_emitter.ts
+++ b/packages/core/src/event_emitter.ts
@@ -61,7 +61,7 @@ import {Subject, Subscription} from 'rxjs';
  * @see [Observables in Angular](guide/observables-in-angular)
  * @publicApi
  */
-export class EventEmitter<T extends any> extends Subject<T> {
+export class EventEmitter<T extends any = void> extends Subject<T> {
   /**
    * @internal
    */
@@ -83,7 +83,7 @@ export class EventEmitter<T extends any> extends Subject<T> {
    * Emits an event containing a given value.
    * @param value The value to emit.
    */
-  emit(value?: T) { super.next(value); }
+  emit(value: T) { super.next(value); }
 
   /**
    * Registers handlers for events emitted by this instance.
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "EventEmitter.emit() should only accept T, not T | undefined." (#35119)

Issues.Title: The `isNode()` detection in the animations module is not precise enough
Issues.Body:
While profiling the issue reported in  #35029  it turned out that [the isNode() detection method](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/4d36b2f6e9a1a7673b3f233752895c96ca7dba1e/packages/animations/browser/src/render/shared.ts#L22-L24), present in the animation module, is not precise enough and can execute in a browser, leading to the performance problems.

![Screenshot 2020-01-31 at 14 41 41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/973550/73641995-2be68d80-4671-11ea-807f-49d50effce6a.png)

Looking at the profiling picture captured in a browser we can notice that `writeStyleAttribute` function is executed, [even if is supposed to execute in the Node environment only](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/b0834fe962b96fc84e5ffbcdb5283b25f74a5c47/packages/animations/browser/src/util.ts#L176-L187)!

 This is unfortunate since the  `writeStyleAttribute` is relatively slow (see #35116) - but the point of this issue here is that it should not execute in a browser at all!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The `isNode()` detection in the animations module is not precise enough" (#35117)

Issues.Title: writeStyleAttribute performance issues
Issues.Body:
While profiling the issue reported in #35029 it turned out that the significant amount of time is spent in the [writeStyleAttribute](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/b0834fe962b96fc84e5ffbcdb5283b25f74a5c47/packages/animations/browser/src/util.ts#L139-L158) function.

Here is the picture visible under profiler:
![Screenshot 2020-01-31 at 14 41 41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/973550/73641342-29cfff00-4670-11ea-8d71-49826de81000.png)

We can notice several things here:
* `writeStyleAttribute` takes most of the time spent in the `_beforeAnimationBuild`;
* was majority of time is spent evaluating a regular expression from `camelCaseToDashCase`;
* it is strange that we iterate over style properties multiple times.

The writeStyleAttribute implementation should be reviewed and improved from the performance point of view.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "writeStyleAttribute performance issues" (#35116)

Issues.Title: ci: remove components-repo-ci blocklist
Issues.Body:
Previously we needed the `components-repo-ci` blocklist to disable
tests that were failing during the development of Ivy. Since we fixed
all those failing tests, and we don't want to regress, we can remove the
blocklist logic.

Resolves FW-1807

Issues.Title: Prod minified code breaks app when using namespace merging
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ bug report ### Affected Package @angular/cli ### Is this a regression? I don't know ### Description I have a very large file structured like this: ```ts export namespace Hello { export function f1() { return setTimeout(() => f2, 1000); } export function f2() { return setTimeout(() => f1, 1000); } // ... Each function has a reference to another function in the same namespace } export namespace Hello { // Repeats as above export function g1() { // ... } } // ... // There are several more all with the same namespace name // each function in each namespace has a unique name, there are no collisions ``` I then dynamically access the namespace using the function names as accessors, i.e. ```ts import { Hello } from './hello'; // get the function name, so we can access Hello; const name = Hello.f1.name; Hello[name] // this will break when AOT/Prod is enabled since variables are renamed // So we do const key = Object.keys(Hello).find(key => Hello[key].name === name) Hello[key] // This doesn't work but should ``` The problem is that when using multiple namespaces that merge during compilation, the way functions are enumerated restarts for each `export namespace Hello { ...`. The problem goes away when only one namespace is used. ## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-issue-repro2-fljw6o **The problem only presents itself when running in production mode with AOT.** **So please download and try locally** The app takes the two namespaces, logs their keys, then logs the names of the functions associated with the keys. You can see that the split up namespace has duplicated function names, while the mono-namespace has unique names. ## ğŸŒ Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 9.0.0-rc.10
Node: 12.14.1
OS: linux x64

Angular: 9.0.0-rc.11

Issues.Title: [POC] feat(language-service): type event variables targeting DOM events
Issues.Body:
The language service is able to type `$event` variables belonging to
outputs, but is currently unable to type events that belong to DOM
events. This commit adds support for typing DOM events by looking up the
TypeScript type of a DOM event in the `HTMLElementEventMap`. A new
module has been added to the Language Service to enable the creation of
a TypeScript program needed for this change.

Note that construction of TypeScript programs is not inexpensive.

Closes https://github.com/angular/vscode-ng-language-service/issues/531.

Issues.Title: Lazy loaded modules do not contain crossorigin attribute
Issues.Body:
<!--ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…

Oh hi there! ğŸ˜„

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…-->


# ğŸ bug report

### Affected Package

@angular-devkit/build-angular

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

Specifying `'crossOrigin: "anonymous"'`  in angular.json makes angular cli to add the corresponding attribute in the <script> elements of the `<body>`, but angular is still not appending it in the lazy loaded modules in the `<head>` during runtime.

Lazy loaded modules will only contain the `crossorigin` attribute hardcoded to 'anonymous', only if "subresourceIntegrity" is true. In this case, also the integrity attribute is added, and in our case this is not desired.

Expected is, that <script> from lazy loaded modules behave in the same way as <script> from angular.


## ğŸŒ  Your Environment

"@angular/cli": "8.3.18",
"@angular/compiler-cli": "8.2.13",
"@angular/language-service": "8.2.13",
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Lazy loaded modules do not contain crossorigin attribute" (#16801)

Issues.Title: vulnerabilities in yarnpkg/lockfile 1.1.0
Issues.Body:
### Description

@angular/cli has dependency of "@yarnpkg/lockfile": "1.1.0",.

According to NVD ([https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-10773](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-10773)), there is security vulnerability that is resolved in 1.21.1.

There is also a second vulnerability documented in 1.17.3:
[https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-5448](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-5448)

Can this package be updated to 1.21.1?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "vulnerabilities in yarnpkg/lockfile 1.1.0" (#16821)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): use translation file in bundle hash calculations
Issues.Body: This change ensures that any changes to translation files is represented in the output file names when output hashing is enabled.  This prevents the situation where a translation file only change to an application would result in built files with no change in output name.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): use translation file in bundle hash calculations" (#16817)

Issues.Title: Allow generation of suffix-free file and symbol names
Issues.Body:
<!--ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…ğŸ”…

# ğŸš€ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- âœï¸edit: -->
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [x] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
<!-- âœï¸--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...

During style guide meetings we discussed that although recommended for most projects, suffixes in names of components, directives, and services in particular could be redundant for some projects.

We'd not change the official style guide recommendation, but we'd want to enable folks with advanced use cases to drop the suffixes when needed.


### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- âœï¸--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.

This proposal is for a global CLI flag per project which disables the current default behavior. When this flag is enabled it'll not suffix any of the generated files, nor the declared symbols inside of them.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- âœï¸--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?

Drop suffixes completely, which is bad for most projects.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Allow generation of suffix-free file and symbol names" (#16811)

Issues.Title: Increased main.js bundle size but less lazy chunks, another case with Angular v9-rc.11 in a monorepo structure
Issues.Body:
# ğŸ Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] serve - [x] build - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, with Angular v8, or Ivy disabled, the main bundle size issue did not happen ### Description Like in issue https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/16146, Ivy enabled builds result in bigger main bundles. We use an app-shell plus lazy load of components- with Angular Elements like in aio, and routes. With View Engine (VE), both in Angular 8 and 9, the main bundle effectively only included what was required to render the shell: * Core framework, * Auth back-end, * Angular Material sidenav and toolbar, * Shell components. Once Ivy is enabled, it includes additional code. E.g., in one application, we get those two source-map-explorer results: ![Captura de pantalla de 2020-01-30 09-41-47](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14163866/73437456-a8652d80-434c-11ea-943c-06cd59a25c8c.png) ![Captura de pantalla de 2020-01-30 09-41-49](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14163866/73437458-a8652d80-434c-11ea-8358-60b6b9e166c9.png) In other app, the result is also bigger main bundles. In particular, it adds all the `@Injectable({providedIn: 'root})` services that are provided in a data-access internal library: ![Captura de pantalla de 2020-01-30 10-45-15](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14163866/73440039-e8c6aa80-4350-11ea-9ea3-cf3afea9f727.png) ![Captura de pantalla de 2020-01-30 10-51-58](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14163866/73440040-e8c6aa80-4350-11ea-9fba-40b51d545b4e.png) ## ğŸ”¬ Minimal Reproduction The issue is in a proprietary mono-repo of front-ends. We can provide access in Bitbucket or Github private repositories if necessary. To generate the bundles, we used ``` ng build --prod --source-map --localize=false ``` And only changed the tsconfig.json to set `angularCompilerOptions.enableIvy = false` ## ğŸŒ Your Environment

Issues.Title: build: remove ngcc postinstall patch in favor of separate script
Issues.Body:
Currently we always patch `ngcc` as part of a postinstall patch. This is
because Ngcc does not overwrite the `main` field of processed packages.

Though, since we want to run `nodejs_binary`/`nodejs_test` targets with
Ivy, we need to either have custom module resolution, or just need to
update the `package.json` files to point to the NGCC processed bundles.

Implementing a custom module resolution for each of these target seems
rather incovenient and less reliable. Instead, we just ensure the
`package.json` files point to the right files.

Currently we achieve this by patching ngcc to always update the `main`
property. This patch is prone to upstream ngcc changes, so we move it
into a separate script that just runs _after_ ngcc, and updates the
`package.json` files. The benfit of this is that `ngcc` doesn't need to
be patched, and upstream ngcc changes are not likely breaking the
components repo unit test (as seen in:
https://circleci.com/gh/angular/angular/608106).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: remove ngcc postinstall patch in favor of separate script" (#18355)

Issues.Title: build: remove unused angular bazel postinstall patch
Issues.Body:
In the past, when the framework repo updated their `rules_nodejs`
version, a patch on the components was needed in order to make the
`components-repo-unit-tests` job on framework green.

Since this update PR already landed, and we updated to the Angular
version that includes these changes, we can remove the patch.

Issues.Title: build: remove test blocklist
Issues.Body:
The blocklist will be no longer used in the framework repository, so
we can remove it from the components repo too.

Related to FW-1807.

Issues.Title: build: add option for running all component tests
Issues.Body:
Adds a `--all` option to the `yarn test` script. This option
can be used to run _all_ component tests in the repository.

Flags like `--no-watch` and `--firefox` can be used in combination with
the new `-all` flag.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: add option for running all component tests" (#18371)

Issues.Title: feat(datepicker): initial styling for date range
Issues.Body:
Reworks a few things in the calendar and adds the styling for the date range. A couple of notes:
* This isn't the final UX of when start/end ranges will be selected. I wanted to have most of the functionality in place before playing around with the UX.
* This approach currently has an issue where the range won't go from one month into another properly. The problem is that the date cells store the current day internally. I'll make a follow-up PR that'll address the issue by storing the timestamp instead.


![Feb-02-2020 20-11-24](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4450522/73613735-c6ef5100-45f8-11ea-9ede-d14a8d33b28d.gif)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(datepicker): initial styling for date range" (#18369)

Issues.Title: fix(youtube-player): handle API interactions before API has loaded
Issues.Body:
Currently if the user tries to interact with the API before the YouTube API has loaded (e.g. by calling `playVideo`) their method call will be ignored. These changes add some logic that will store the state and replay it once the player has been initialized.

Fixes #18279.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(youtube-player): handle API interactions before API has loaded" (#18368)

Issues.Title: build: update to latest MDC Canary version
Issues.Body:
Updates to the latest MDC Canary to try and resolve the build errors in the CI check on master.

**Note:** I was going to do this together with #18367, but I had to do a weird workaround so I decided to decouple it from the Angular update which went smoothly. See the code comments below for more context.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: update to latest MDC Canary version" (#18366)

Issues.Title: build: update to latest Angular RC
Issues.Body: Updates to Angular 9.0.0-rc.13 and resolves an issue with one of the postintall patches.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: update to latest Angular RC" (#18367)

Issues.Title: fix(ng-add): do not overwrite version range specified in `ng add`
Issues.Body:
The CLI inserts requested dependencies into the `package.json` before
`ng add` schematics run. This means that we usually do not need to insert
the dependency into `package.json` files.

Alternatively, it could happen that the `ng add` schematics run outside of
the CLI `ng add` command, or the requested dependency is dev only. In those
cases we insert a version based on the current version placeholder.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ng-add): do not overwrite version range specified in `ng add`" (#18365)

Issues.Title: refactor: rename `nav` schematic to `navigation`
Issues.Body:
Our docs often describe the `nav` schematic as `navigation` schematics,
and it's not quite clear what the actual schematic name is. To avoid
this confusion, we just name it `navigation`, but keep support for
the old `nav` abbreviation.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor: rename `nav` schematic to `navigation`" (#18364)

Issues.Title: build: minor improvements to testing script
Issues.Body:
* Currently the test script doesn't support doing something like `yarn test material/stepper`, instead we have to pass in `src/material/stepper` explicitly. These changes make it so that we don't have to pass in `src`, because it's easy to forget.
* Makes it so we exit the process, rather than throw an error when a target isn't found. This makes it easier to locate the error message since there won't be a large stack trace moving it up.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: minor improvements to testing script" (#18363)

Issues.Title: feat(drag-drop): add option to match size of dragged element in custom preview
Issues.Body:
By default we don't resize custom previews, because we'd have to make assumptions about what the consumer wants to show. These changes add the `matchSize` input which allows the consumer to opt into matching the custom preview size to the dragged element size.

Fixes #18177.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(drag-drop): add option to match size of dragged element in custom preview" (#18362)

Issues.Title: docs: update dev environment instructions
Issues.Body:
Updates the dev environment instructions to mention how to run tests properly.

Also removes global Gulp as a required step for setting up the environment and changes the Gulp commands to go through yarn.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "docs: update dev environment instructions" (#18359)

Issues.Title: Maps update
Issues.Body: Moves recent changes from master into google-maps-next, so that new components can be altered to use the NgZone fix from pull request 18034
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Maps update" (#18358)

Issues.Title: fix(radio): clicks not landing correctly in some cases on Chrome
Issues.Body: This is along the same lines as #18285 since the radio button and slide toggle have a very similar setup. Whenever the radio button host receives focus we forward it immediately to the underlying input, but this bouncing around of focus could cause clicks to be interrupted in some cases. These changes make it so that we only move focus if the host was focused by the keyboard or mouse.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(radio): clicks not landing correctly in some cases on Chrome" (#18357)

Issues.Title: fix(drag-drop): error when dragging items inside transplanted views with OnPush change detection
Issues.Body:
This is a bit of an edge case, but nevertheless it's something that can happen. The way the dragging sequence works is that the drop list keeps track of its items via `ContentChildren` and it registers itself with them once they're picked up by the `QueryList`. If an item doesn't have a container when the drag sequence is started, it is considered a "standalone" drag.

This becomes a problem with transplanted views (e.g. ones created by `cdk-table`) that use OnPush where we could end up in a situation where the items aren't picked up during the first pass, but when the user starts dragging, we trigger change detection and the `QueryList` is updated, but at that point it's too late, because we've already started the dragging sequence with a different set of information.

These changes work around the issue by assigning the container manually again through the drag directive.

A couple of notes:
* This is a second iteration of the fix. I went with this approach, because it doesn't require hacky timeouts and triggering change detection again. See the origin approach here: https://github.com/angular/components/commit/22afc3723258e6431b4603d96442daaffaa02f22
* It's difficult to capture this in a test, because we'd have to duplicate half of the logic from `CdkTable` and we might still not be able to get the same change detection timing due to `TestBed`.

Fixes #18341.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(drag-drop): error when dragging items inside transplanted views with OnPush change detection" (#18356)

Issues.Title: docs(datepicker): add dayjs date adapter documentation
Issues.Body:
## What I Did
- First pass at adding documentation for [MatDayjsDateAdapter](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@tabuckner/material-dayjs-adapter) in response to https://github.com/angular/components/issues/18337
_Note: I am more than happy to have this absorbed if that is in any way appealing._

## Why
Moment adds a lot of overhead in regards to Locales, Day.js allows users to pick and choose that locales they want to include. There is still some improvement to be made on the package around configuring what locales are included, but the approach offered by [Jan van Rossum](https://github.com/vanrossumict) in [this PR](https://github.com/tabuckner/material-dayjs-adapter/pull/1 works just fine).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "docs(datepicker): add dayjs date adapter documentation" (#18354)
